div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, AUGUST 1, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is £ 9 to Brindisi.
The combined sea and special train fare has been reduced to £ 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Mersailles.

During the Monsoon season the express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

div.p: The Planets
Mercury is an evening staar at the beginningof the month and becomes invisible at the close.
Venus is a morning star throughout the month.
Mars sets at midnight at the beginning of the month and a little before 11 a.m. at the close.
Jupiter rises a little after midnight at the beginning of the month and at 11.15 p.m. at the close.
Saturn rises at 8 p.m. at the beginning of the month and at 6 p.m. at the close.
The chief constellations in the South at 9 p.m. are Aquila near the zenith (chief star, Altair) and Sagittarius about 30 above the horizon.

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.
Egyptian Finances

The highly satisfactory state of the finances of the Egyptian Government is made manifest in the lastest supplement to the "Official Journal," which contains the accounts for June, with tables showing the revenue and expenditure of the country during the first six months of 1905. The reciepts for this period amount to L.E. 6,391,048 against L.E. 5,972,848 last year as an improvement of L.E. 418,200 for which the increase in the revenue of the Railway Administration, a good index of the commercial prosperity of the country, is largely responsible. Tobacco and Customs duties show a gratifying increase, and the Post Office will to all appearance end the year with a very substantial balance. The expenditure for the first six months of 1905 shows an increase of L.E. 441,536 on the figures for the same period in 1904. The Railway Administration shows the largest increase, which is of course explained by the large purchases of new material that have been and are being made, purchase which will aid the State Railways to become one of the chief sources of Egypt's revenue.

div.head:
GERMANY & THE BALTIC.
THE PROJECTED CLOSING.
SEMI-OFFICIAL DENIALS.

div.p: The newspapers are concerned about the antagonism created by Germany s pretention to proclaim the Baltic as a closed sea, and by England's resolution to come and make a naval demonstration as a protest. (Havas.)
The semi-official journals deny that Ger- many entertains any projects of closing the Baltic Sea. (Reuter.)
The Russians at Rykoff numbered 5,000 Infantry with 12 guns. (Reuter.)
The Emperor William has sailed for Copen- hagen on a visit to the Danish Court. (Reuter.)

The Council of Ministers has approved the electoral scheme for a National Assembly. Everyone will be enfranchised who is over 25 years and fulfils the prescribed property and taxation qualifications. Each province and 20 of the largest towns will elect an electoral college, which will in its turn elect the de- puties. Voting will be by secret ballot through- out. The peasants will have no individual votes. Their collegiate representatives will be elected by the communal councils. (Reuter.)

div.head:
NO DISSOLUTION IN THE AUTUMN.
UNLESS GOVERNMENT IS RE-DEFEATED..

div.p: The "Daily Telegraph" says that it is in a position to state that no dissolution will take place in the autumn unless the Government is again defeated." (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE CRETAN DISTURBANCES.
MARTIAL LAW PROCLAIMED.

div.p: The insurgents having refused to accept the Consuls' intimation, mentioned on the 16th instant, as sufficient, the latter have proclaimed martial law in the island. (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE PEACE COMMISSION.
SENSATIONAL PRESS REPORTS.

div.p: Owing to sensational interviews published by the American Press regarding the terms of peace, M. Sato has bean obliged to announce that they are fabrications or misquotations. He is ignorant of the Japanese terms. (R)

The French councillors will hold a special business meeting while they are in London. (Reuter.)

div.head: Rotations.—
div.p: A table of rotations for Ghar- bieh province is published in yesterday's "Journal Officiel" in lieu of that published in last Saturday's issue, which is cancelled.

div.head: Hashish Den Discovered.—
div.p: A cafe at Sa- galla was raided by the police yesterday, and proofs were found that the place was used for gambling and hashish smoking. A proces-verbal has been drawn up against the proprietor.

Suez Canal.—18 vessels passed through the Canal on the 28th inst., of which 12 were British, 3 German, 1 French, 1 Russian, 1 Dutch. The day's receipts were frs. 471,570.79, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 8,294,834.63.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.—
div.p: The talented artistes recently engaged by the management will give another concert at the Casino on Thurs- day next, accompanied by the Bracale orchestra. The programme will be published to-morrow.

div.head: Khedive's Birthday Anniversary.—
div.p: To- morrow, being the anniversary of the birthday of his Highness the Khedive, all public offices will be closed and the day observed as a general holiday throughout the country. A salute of 31 guns will be fired at noon from the Citadel, Cairo, and also at Alexandria and Port Said.

div.head: Cattle Plague.—
div.p: During the week ending July 29, 30 deaths from cattle plague were notified throughout Egypt, namely, 16 at Kalioub, 4 at Hehia, 5 at Chibin-el-Kom, 1 at Tala, 2 at Kouesna, and 2 at Menouf. The number of deaths during the cor- responding period last year was 724. The total number of deaths since the commence- ment of the epidemic amounts to 147,416, viz., Gouvernorats 894, Lower Egypt 54,275, Upper Egypt 92,247.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.—
div.p: Fifteen cases were in all reported in Egypt during last week. Of these, 10 occurred at Alexandria, one at Port Said, one at Ashmoun, 2 at Goreis (Menoufieh dis- trict), and one at Matarieh (Dekerness dis- trict). Seven cases ended fatally, namely, 5 natives and one European at Alexandria and one native at Ashmoun. Eight cures have been effected, namely, 5 at Alexandria, 2 at Ashmoun, and one at Toukh. Yesterday's bulletin was a clean sheet and recorded five recoveries at Ashmoun.

div.head: Post Office Notice. —
div.p: The continual in- crease in the demand for house-to-house deli- very in Cairo and Alexandria renders it absolutely necessary that all persons in these towns desirous of such delivery shall have the number of the house and name of the street in which they live indicated on their correspon- dence. Should by any chance a street be unnamed, then the quarter of the town in which it is situated must be indicated, Atten- tion to these Instructions is imperative to avoid delay and errors in the delivery of correspond- ence.

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce.—
div.p: We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer- chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appointing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual sub- scription is merely the nominal one of £1. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquirers can obtain farther particulars from our London office, 86, New Broad-street, which sets as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: THE COTTON WORM.
HOPEFUL OUTLOOK.
div.p: In a recent issue we pointed out that the measures which had been taken by the Mi- nistry of the Interior for the destruction of the cotton worm had proved most effective, and we have now received further information from the Ministry which indicates that the hopes which we expressed of the August brood (which is as a rule the most extensive and destructive of the three broods,) being slight, are by no means unfounded. The information to which we refer is that the reports from the province of Menoufieh show that no new eggs or cotton worm have been found in Menouf Markaz since the 18th inst., in Chibin and Kouesna since the 19th inst., and in Tala only a small number has been found and these are confined to an area of two feddans. The cotton in the Menoufieh province is particularly fine this year, and owing to the precautions which have been enforced by the Ministry of the Interior, no damage to the cotton crops has been sustained.
The Ministry of the Interior has issued the following note:-

"With reference to the note on this subject issued by the Ministry on the 1st July, 1905, it has been found that in certain districts cultivators have not understood that every effort must be directed towards the destruction of the Aphis or small green fly as soon as it appears. As explained in the circular, the suction of this fly does not actually destroy the leaves, though undoubtedly its action fends to enfeeble them, but, as they feed, they deposit a sticky kind of honey. This sticky substance in due coarse attracts the spores of a sooty fungus which is carried on the wind and settles wherever it is found. Many culti- vators say, with reason, that the "Nedwet El Assal" comes later, but it must be clearly understood that, so far, when the "Nedwa" comes it has been found impossible to deal with it. The only thing to do is to destroy the "aphis" whenever it appears by spraying, if hand pumps are available, otherwise by pick- ing and burning the leaves, or even when necessary by uprooting a certain number of plants. Any leaves on which the sticky sub- stance is found must also be picked and burn- ed, so that when the "Nedwa" comes now or later, there may be nothing to attract it and it will pass by. Ail this is set forth in the original circular, but as confusion still appears to exist in tho minds of many cultivators, it is of the greatest importance that immediate steps should be taken to explain to all concerned. The "aphis" and the "assal" have already been detected in many localities, and in certain districts where there have lately been heavy mists in the early morning, the "Nedwa" has descended upon the affected leaves and the plants turn black and die. Urge the cultivators to search for the "aphis" and the "assal," When the "Nedwa" comes it is too late."

div.head: NEW CREDITS.
div.p: The following new credits have been open- ed :—L.E. 2,000 for the improvement of the streets of Luxor, L.E. 20,000 for the new prison to be constructed near the Delta Barra- ge, L.E. 5,000 for the enlargement of the Abu Zaabal prison, L.E. 29,500 for the construc- tion of a barracks at Ras el Tin, L.E.20,000 for new irrigation works in the Fayoum, and L.E. 11,400 for the enlargement of the Lunatic Asylum at Abbassieh.

div.head: PORT SAID'S TRADE.
WINE IMPORTS.
div.p: Port Said only plays a small part in the import trade in wines. The prices usual at Port Said are as follows for cases 12 bottles eaoh f.o.b. Port Said : light sherry 15 frs., Manganilla 20 frs., Amontillado 22 frs., Ma- deira 19 frs., Malaga 17 frs. The red table wines imported from France arrive as a rule in barrels containing from 200 to 220 litres, with an average price of 30 frs, the hectolitre franco Marseilles. The white and red wines of Palestine are getting more and more into favor and are delivered at 33 centimes the litre. The excellent wines produced by the Jewish Colony of Richon-le-Zion are success- fully competing—despite their higher price- with the Italian wines—Brindisi, Bari, Trani, Barletta, etc.—which usually cost from 20 to 30 frs. f.o.b. Port Said. Greek wines are sold by the kilo at from 16 to 18 centimes per kilo. Were the freights lower the cheaper Austrian table wines would be able to compete with a good chance of success, but as freight charges from Marseilles to Port Said only amount to 10 frs, per cubic metre, while those on the Austria Lloyd boats are double as high, it is not likely that they can be profitably imported. Hungarian wines, however, are likely to gain some ground in Alexandria and Cairo.

div.head: TURKISH PRISON LIFE
AN INCIDENT AT BEYROUT.
div.p: Last week a riot took place in the prison at Beyrout which was a flagrant instance of looseness of control. Halim Zreik, a famous Christian outlaw who has ended in jail, seems to have been promised by a body of Moslem prisoners a bribe of £50, to be paid him after the accomplishment of a murderous deed on another Christian prisoner, a certain Iskandar Nims, to avenge one of their co-religionists who had been murdered by the latter. Zreik attempt- ed to murder Nims by two sudden stabs with a dagger, which brought the victim to the ground with two dangerous wounds in the shoulder.

The act censed a fanatical outbreak among the Christian and Moslem prisoners, which was not quelled until the tardy in- terference of the police, who, having imper- fectly disarmed the rioters,—oh ! the irony of things in Turkey—gave occasion for a recru- descence of the same trouble on the following day. The incident, though followed by no very serious consequences, shows the dangerous unsoundness of the base on which rests the institution that is supposed to safeguard public safety and order.

If you pass by the prison at Beyrout you hear sounds of merriment and laughter, which show that the inmates are not only bearing prison-life lightly but are in a way enjoying it. In fact, the relatives of prisoners are allowed to bring to the latter food and every kind of delicacy, while inside the prison card-playing and music are allowed as freely as they would be in a cafe. The post of jailer is a lucrative one, for it is at the same time that of a caterer to the enjoyment of the prisoners in his charge. Indeed, his profits accrue not only from acts of active service, but also from connivance at irregularities committed. Imprisonment under these conditions becomes an attraction, especially to vagabonds and born idlers, and that is why imprisonment in Turkey defeats its end in a certain measure.

One would have thought that the cellular prisons in Cyprus, with all the perfections of new methods, would have served as an object- lesson and a model for Turkish penal institu- tions, but such unfortunately has not been the case. The corruption in Turkish prisons is appalling, and the contrast between the latter and modern European prison-houses is painful to all who care to see Turkey improve and prosper. Turkish prisons are simply halls of convivial pleasures catered to by venal indulgence, and they must seem strange abodes for the punishment of crime to those who know something of European cellular prisons, where vigilant severity makes life to the prisoner, as it should, a dreadful burden.

Penal institutions are the safeguards of public safety and order, and affeot indireotly a na- safety and order, and it is therefore devoutly to be hoped that adequate attention will be paid by the authorities to the existing evil in Turkish prisons.

div.head: DAR FUR
div.p: It is reported that Ali Dinar, Sultan of Dar Fur, has been engaged in hostilities against the Massalit, a savage negroid tribe whose territories lie between Kebkebieh and the Sultanate of Wadai. Another branch of this people inhabits Wadai and is said to be under Senoussi influence. The Massalit played a considerable part in the campaign of 1881-2 against Slatin Pasha, and later joined the "false Mahadi," About Gemaizeh, himself of Massalit origin, and were very severely defeated by the Dervishes under Osman Wad Adam at El Fasher in 1889.

div.head: NOTES FROM THE SUDAN.
div.p: RAINS AND CROPS.
( From our Correspondent ).
Khartoum, July 23.

Though heavy rains have fallen early this year in the Southern Sudan, the Nile has risen very slowly compared with last season. The cultivators have already begun sowing (with- out ploughing, as they do not know how to do this) their fields of maize, and hope to have a very good crop. They have greatly suffered during the past four years owing to the scarcity of rain.
STARVING NATIVES.

The ardeb of dura is worth at present P.T. 120, and it will probably within three months fall to P.T. 30. This fall in price will prove a great boon to the already half-starved population of some parts of the interior of the Sudan, as I understand that a great many people have been eating the roots of the trees in the forests.
SALES OF LAND.

The scarcity of rain has also led numerous landowners to dispose of their lands at a very low price to the Greek merchants settling in the larger towns. The Government, realising the great harm which the peasants were causing to their own future welfare, have issued a proclamation to the effect that no land is to be sold without the special approval of the governors of the provinces concerned.
THE WILY GREEK.

It has come to my knowledge that the factor which led these merchants to acquire large areas of land is the prospect of the proposed canal to be built next year through the Ghezireh, i.e., the land lying between the Blue and White Niles. The Government are to be congratulated on having taken such a wise course, as I feel sure that had they not done so all the land would have passed into the hands of strangers, and the natives would have been left poor and miserable.
VISITATION OF LOCUSTS.

Myriads of locusts have passed over Ghezireh on their way South, but they are causing little or no anxiety, as no crop is grown at the present time of the year, and their eggs, when deposited, will be destroyed by the rains.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Hussein Pasha and Prince Ibrahim Pasha Fouad have arrived at Alexandria from Cairo.

Mr. F. G. Morgan, the United States Vice- Consul General at Cairo, has ordered a 20 horse- power Renault automobile in Paris. This will be fitted with Kellner-Dorsay body, painted out- side blue with thin turquoise stripes, and will be used by Mr. Morgan as a city vehicle in Cairo.
El Lewa E. Mansfield Pasha, Commandant of the Cairo City Police, will resume duty on October 30.
Mr. Tottenham, who arrived at Cairo on Sunday, is leaving almost immediately for the Sudan, where he will replace Mr. Dupuis during the latter's absence on leave.
Mr. H. Carter Wilson, director of Personnel and Accounts Dept., has returned from leave and resumed duty at the Ministry of the Interior.

Mr. E. W. Wortabet, whose services were lent to the Ministry of the Interior for cotton- worm duty by the Imperial Ottoman Bank, has been struck off the list of the temporary em- ployes of the Ministry, his work being com- pleted. He resumed duty at the Ottoman Bank to-day.
Leave has been granted to Mr. M. Macdonald, director of the Assouan Barrage, for three months, to date from the 5th inst.
Abdulla Bey Azion, director, Ministers' Division, has been granted 3 1/2 months' leave of absence, dating from Saturday last.

Class I
Class II
Class I. Course C.
Class II. Course O.

Those sailing in Class II., Course O., are re- quested to note that owing to an extension being made to the breakwater, when they are coming in from the Boghas beacon to Gabbary they must keep well dear of the breakwater lighthouse and leave on the port hand a buoy to the S.W. of the same which will have a mark boat with flag attached to it Yachts leaving this marie boat on the starboard hand and passing between it and the breakwater lighthouse will be disqualified, besides running the risk, if they are deep-draught boats, of grounding.

In Class I., as the Minnie and Coot "tied" last month on points for the monthly prize and their relative handicap this week is the same, the first one of these two in to-morrow's race will win last month's prize irrespective of the cup being sailed for.
A. S. C. GYMKHANA.

Saturday's Gymkhana attracted but a small number of people to the A. S. C. grounds, and the enclosure bore almost a deserted appearance. This is not to be wondered at when we condider how many are absent in Europe, but still we think that the Gymkhana on the whole is not popular. Beyond those who took an active part in the programme on Saturday, everyone seemed more or less bored, and this is sometimes the oast at these meetings. With these introductory remarks we shall pass on to the events.

The first event was a Bending Race, com- petitors having to ride their ponies in and out a row of flags. There were numerous entries for this race, which was run in heats, and eventually Mr. Harold Carver won from Mr. Bartlett. The Postillion Race which followed was an interesting event, competitors having to ride 200 yards leading a bareback pony, dismount, change the saddle to the other pony, and gallop book to the winning post, leading the unsaddled pony. Mr. Trafford easily secured the verdict in this event. A number of ladies and gentlemen took part in the Mathematical Race, and the first to pass the post was Mr. Bartlett, but unfortunately his partner had made a mistake in the addition sum given her, and the prize went to Mrs. Williams, for whom Mr. A. A Carver rode. The Captivity Stakes and Motor Car Bending Race did not attract competitors, and had therefore to be abandoned. As a substitute there was a race for children, who were handicapped accord- ing to their age, and a close and pretty rare ended in Mister Briscoe securing the prize. Only two teams entered for the Lloyd Lindsay competition, one from the R. Berks. Regiment and the other a civilian team. The former, composed of Major Finch, Capt. Bingley, Mr. Bassett, and Mr. Bartlett, won some- what easily, their time being half a minute less than the losers. The Apple Race produced considerable amusement and was eventually won by Mr. Bartlett, riding for Mrs. Macpherson-Grant At the close of the programme, a Hack Scurry was got up and produced five entries. It was well won by Mr. A. A. Carver. At the conclusion Baroness von Humboldt-Dachroeden kindly undertook to distribute the prizes to the various winners. The band of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berk- shire Regiment, as usual, furnished the music and added considerably to the enjoyment of the afternoon, which was, climatically, very pleasant.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: EXERCICE 1901
RECETTES
L03 prévisions budgétaires étaient de L.E. 172.000 ; les recettes réalisées ont atteint L.E. 189.581, accusant une plus-value de L.E. 17.581.

Les droits sur les exportations et les impor- tations, le produit de la taxe sur les voitures et. les bêtes de somme, l'impôt sur la propriété bâtie, le produit de la taxe de 2 %, les recettes do l'Abattoir, les droits d'exploitation des car- rières du Mex, les droits du Tanzim ainsique les recettes diverses, ont donné un excédent de plus de L.E. 20.500, ce qui a permis de combler les diminutions de L.E/3.000 pro-, venant des recettes de l'asphaltage 3es trottoirs, de la retenue sur les traitements du personnel classé pour le Fonds de Prévoyance ainsi que le déficit sur les prévisions de la moitié du produit de la vente des biens libres et la location des immeubles libres de l'Etat. Il y a, lieu de noter toutefois que ces quatre derniers chefs ne constituent pas des taxes et droits purement municipaux. Dans l'ensemble, la situation est satisfaisante, les recettes ayant donné une plus-value de L.E. 17.581.
Les divers chefs de recettes pour 1904 ac cusent également une plus-value sensible sur ceux de 1903. Les chefs suivants méritent une mention spéciale :

Taxe sur les voitures et bêtes de somme.—Les réalisations en 1904 ont atteint LE. 8.205, contre L.E. 7.110 en 1903. Cette augmentation des recettes constatée sur un ohef qui dimi- nuait constamment^ depuis la suppression de l'Octroi, est due à un contrôle plus rigoureux exercé à partir du 2me semestre de l'exercice 1904 sur la perception de cette taxe. Je suis convaincu que, grâce à la nouvelle organisation du Service des Recettes et à l'application des reçus nominatifs à partir du 1er janvier dernier, les réalisations atteindront en 1905 un chiffre plus rapproché du vrai montant que cette taxe pourrait nous rendre.
Impôt sur la propriété bâtie et taxe du 2 / sur les loyers.— Les recettes de 1904 dépassent celles de 1903 de LE. 4.533 et LE. 1.457 respectivement.
Arriérés de Diverses Taxes a Fin 1904.
Taxe de 2 %.— Les arriérés à fin 1904 s'é- lèvent à L.E. 3.C27 contre L.E. 5.446 à fin 1903. Ils se décomposent comme suit :
Solde des arriérés de 1900 jusqu'à 1903 L.E. 2.848; arriérés de l'exercice 1904 L.E. 779. De ce montant il y a lieu de déduire :
1° Les sommes dues par divers contribuables sur la taxe des exercices 1900, 1901 et 1902 qui sont introuvables et dont les noms ne figu- rent pas dans les recensements de 1903 et 1904 LE. 1.881.
2° Montant irrecouvrable sur les taxes des exercices 1900, 1901,1902 et 1903 par suite de décès, double recensement, pauvreté, eto. LE. 835. ;■ .
3° Montant irrecouvrable sur la taxe de l'exercice 1904 par suite de décès, double re- censement, pauvreté, etc. L.E. 568.
Le solde se décompose comme suit : Solde des arriérés à fin 1903 L.E. 132; solde des ar- riérés de l'exercice 1904 L.E. 211. De ces .sommes il a été recouvré à ce jour L.E. 210.

Taxe sur la propriété bâtie.— Les arriérés à fin 1904 s'élèvent à L.E. 2.160 contre LE. 3.022 à fin 1903. Ils se décomposent comme suit : Solde des arriérés de 1900 à fin 1903 LE. 372. Arriérés de l'exercice 1904 LE. 1.788. De ces sommes il a été recouvré à ce jour L.E. 1.197.

Taxe sur les véhicules et bétes de somme.— Les arriérés à fin 1904 s'élèvent à LE. 724 contre LE. 967 à fin 1903. Ils se décom- posent- comme suit : Solde des arriérés de 1899 à fin 1903 LE. 410. Arriérés de 1904 L.E. 314. De ce montant il y a lieu de déduire : Les taxes irrécouvrables pour décès, pauvreté, double recensement, etc., qui s'élèvent à L.E. 330. Du solde, L.E. 394, il a été recouvré à ce jour LE. 172.
Récapitulation des arriérés à fin 190J, dont ta perception sera poursuivie en 1905 : Taxe de 2% LE. 343. Taxe sur la propriété bâtie L.E. 2.160. Taxe sur le3 véhicules et animaux L.E! 394.

Droits dabatage. — Comparativement aux réalisations de, 1903 et aux prévisions budgé- taires de 1904,' ces droits accusent une aug- mentation ; mais il y a lieu de remarquer qu'à partir du mois d'Août de l'année dernière ces revenus subissent une diminution iaquiétante pour l'équilibre de notre budget. Cette diminu- tion est due à l'autorisation accordée par les Services Sanitaires à l'armée d'occupation, d'a- battre au Caire, et à la permission donnée d'in- troduire, vivants, dans l'intérieur, les animaux de Syrie et de l'étranger qui étaient au- paravant abattus à Alexandrie. La Délé- gation s'est vivement préoccupée de la situation créée à nos recettes par cet état de choses, et la question, qui a donné lieu à un échangede correspondanceavéoleMinistère, est actuellement à l'examen des Comités du Con- tentieux et des Finances.

Droits de. Tanzim.— En éliminant le3 sommes perçues pour vente des excédents, l'augmenta- tion dans les droits du Tanzim, comparativ ment à l'exercice- 1903, a été de L.E. 68 K Toutefois, je considère que cet excédent ne ré- pond pas encore à ce qu'on est en droit d'at tendre, vu les étendues actuellement occupées delà voie publique. J'e-père pourtant qu'avec l'augmentation du personnel du Tanzim, qui permet d'exercer en ville une plus stricte sur- veillance, ces recettes augmenteront tout en maintenant l'occupation de la voie publique dans les limites des roksa3 et en empêchant les occupations abusives dans certains quar- tiers de la ville oh la circulation pourrait od être gênée. L'institution du corps de la Police Mnnioipale aura également pour effet d'exercer un contrôle pins efficace sur les personnes qui habituellement enoombrent indûment la voie puhliquo.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 25.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 8 Aout 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les redressement de la rue des Baidaoui."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 8 Aout 1905 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 29 juillet 1905.

div.head: WOMEN AND LYING.
div.p: It is amazing that anyone should be found to doubt the fact that women lie more con- stantly, laboriously, and cleverly than men, and in larger proportion. The wonder is that any woman speaks the truth. There are only no ways of being a really lovable, womanly woman. One is to be born so. The other way is to lie long and loud, and as well as ever you can.

Take appearance as the very first instance. The man goes about in his own outlines, and the shape of his head is irretrievably what his Maker willed it; if his hair is straight, it says so. A woman is a creature of broad and gradual curves, whose first duty it is to persuade you that she is the shape of the fashionable corset, which is more or less the shape of the old fashioned hour-glass. If her hair is straight, she waves it; she pads it to the shape she wants ; she curls it to make the "low brow" the novelists now adore out of the bare and lofty forehead that they once grovelled to. In short, she finds out just what she would look like if her appearance told the truth—and hastily ensures, at considerable expense, that u shall "stop that!" When she is thoroughly and irredeemably plain, with no magnetism to help her to lie about it, she will tell the truth in her person. The grey and scanty hair will strain cheerfully back from the knobby fore- head, the untrammelled figure will assert itself in riotous comfort, the serviceable feet will pound untortured in the serviceable boots. She will have leisure to turn her mind from lies and open it to truth and kindness. Men will acknowledge her to be the salt of the earth and turn to its sugar with all the keener zest. They will recommend bar warmly, cordially, as the potential mother of a friend's offspring. For the mother of their own they will turn to the liar.

After appearance, take feelings. Take espe- cially the feelings concerned with sex. What happens to the woman who says, or even implies, "I have the warmest affection for your person, the strongest esteem for your character. If you are inclined to spend your life with me, I will praise heaven fasting" Let a man say these words, and he is "manly," which means "straightforward." Let a woman say them, or show that they are in her heart, and it is ten chances to one that the man will turn from her to the woman who has all the pretty evasive tricks that are the graceful children of a lie. The lie leads to any amount of delicate fencing and the enjoyment of much fluttering of sentiment and suspense. It would be a pity to abolish it. But it is a lie. It has another name, which is "proper self-respect." (The appearance business has another name too. It is called, "making the most of your- self. " )

There was once a girl frankly and devot- edly anxious to marry the man she loved. Her friends pursued her with advice. She was not to make herself cheap. She was to rouse his jealousy if she could. She was to "put him off" with this lie and "bring him on" with another. The girl listened. And when the time came, she got up and put her hands in his, and said gravely and softly, "With all my heart." That answered, for the man was worth what she felt for him. Most of his kind would be the same if they were left alone. They are trained to love the lie, and follow it in women, and to despise it among themselves. After feelings, take views. Many a woman has a man's outlook on life. If she lets the average man see that she has it, especially (again) where sex matters are concerned, she will almost certainly alienate his love by destroying her "mystery" (another deli- ciously interesting lie). She may gain his friendship and companionship, but she will have to take her chance and "rough it" amongst his other friends. "I don't put myself out for Bertha," said a man the other day ; "there's no nonsense about her." And he let her open the heavy gate and push her bicycle through.

After views, take tastes. The constant society of children, for instance, may bore and exasperate a woman. It is as much as her life is worth to say so. Her husband, equally their parent, runs no risk of being avoided as un- natural if he prefers to travel in a different railway compartment from half-a-dozen moist- ish people under ten, whose idea of a July afternoon in a confined space is perpetual motion and whose conversation is a stiff exami- nation paper. If their mother's tenderness does not extend to their bibs and feeding-bottles, she is assumed to have none. She had much better lie, and be a worried hag at forty-five.

If a garden becomes an insupportable weari- ness to her as soon as the flowers materialise, so to .speak, from visions of colour and perfume that carry her thoughts into fairyland, and show themselves to be things that need cultiva- tion and suffer from disease, she is rather un womanly. She had better lie ; and if she can d( it in four hundred pages of print, illustratec by photos that show to the herd that "come: of the garden" that might have been so secre a pleasaunce of delights too sweet to prate of so much the better for her.

In society, the lies appertaining to hospi- tality are almost entirely left to her. The; need not be dwelt upon. They are only decencies, after all, and deceive no one ; and men are not exempt from them.

In marriage, roughly speaking, the more she lies the more smoothly things will go.' It called 'having a little tact." From the time Scheherazade told a thousand and one lies to her lord to save her head, to "present day, when wives are telling a thousand and two to keep the peace, it has been the most accepted way. They should not be the guilty and cum- brous lies of intrigue; but the kind little lie that make married life possible, and the ides wife immune from all other duties except ordering dinner and rearing people who, from the moment of "making the best of them- selves" in girlhood, to "having a little tact" wedlock, will be painstaking, conscientious and probably satisfactory and successful liars.

div.head: SWEET LAVENDER.
div.p: When Eppie in "Silas Marner" was pleading for a little-garden outside the weaver's cottage, she mentions some of the flowers she would like. "I'll have a bit o' rosemary, and bergamot and thyme, because they are so sweet smelling, but there's no lavender only in the gentlefolks' gardens, I think." Her lover instantly hastens to assure her that he will procure her some from the Squire's domain. Though now com- mon enough in cottage gardens, it was not so familiar an object at the time that George Eliot wrote. Its grey-green foliage, Spenser's "Lav- ender still grey," even now stands out with an alien effect among the usual grass-green leaves of our garden plants. The hairy foliage of a plant generally denotes that its original home is in climes where the heat is greater than in England, and where plants find it an advan- tage to have a thick garment of hairs so as to reduce transpiration to a minimum. Introduced into England from Naples as long ago as 1568 lavender only slowly found its way to be the ornament of the flower garden by its bue as by its fragrance, for does it not find a place in Bacon's list of "Sweet-smelling Herbes," although a few years later Gerarde know it, and has figured it in his herbal ? Possibly another reason for its slow acceptance in the English garden was the belief prevalent at one time, that the asp made the bush of lavender its habitual place of abode. The superstition prob- ably came from abroad, when the plant was introduced, for the asp, a species of viper, would be much more common on the arid heat- laden scrub of Southern Europe than in England. Perhaps akin to this idea is the belief prevalent in Tuscany that when worn on the person, it will counteract the Evil eye on little children.

The lavender's original home was in the countries bordering on the Mediterranean, including Northern Africa, although it does not reach Asia Minor. We may, however, justly say that, alien though it is, it has been naturalised so well that it has made England the place where it attains its choicest growth. The lavender water of perfume distilled from the blossoms of the Hitchin or Mitcham lavender fields is better than any to be obtained on the Continent, where perfume- making is so large a feature of trade. Eng- land can claim the premier position in the production of lavender and peppermint, for its moist and moderate climate allows the plant to attain a mildness of fragrance which is not possible in its native habitats. Eng- lish lavender extract realises eight times the price of that produced elsewhere, and also is fully worth the difference for delicacy of odour. Lavender would seem to have been known for its cool, delightful scent many years ago. "The ancients," says an old writer, "employed the flowers and the leaves to aromatise their baths and to give a sweet scent to the water in which they washed, hence the generic name of the plant—La van- dula. Probably the Elder Pliny, though he does not specially mention the lavender, knew all about the plant, growing as it does, so freely as a wild shrub in the hilly districts of Italy. The Romans loved all sorts of sweet scents, both in their houses and at their meals, and in their baths. Our garden lavender is the Lavandula vera. From ano- ther species, the Lavandula spica, we pro- cure the oil of spike used by painters, and also that strongly-scented oil of lavender used as an embrocation in rheumatic affec- tions. Turner, the Father of English Bota- ny, suggests another use for it. "I judge," says he, "that the flowers of Lavender quilted in a cappe and dayly worne are goode for all diseases of the heade that come of a bold cause and that they comfort the braine very well" Certainly the bitter oil has stimulat- ing qualities. Possibly, this is also the rea- son that Perdita classes in her list of flowers hot lavender-mints, savory and majoram, all pleasant aromatic plants— "these are flowers of middle summer, and I think they are given to men of middle age."

Sometimes the lavender was used in the water in which the linen was washed. Prior says the name is derived from the German Lavendal, mid-Latin lavendula, to wash. "Laundress" comes from the same root, Coridon in the "Compleat Angler" says that at the Inn at Waltham where they are to meet there are "fresh sheets that smell of lavender." A sprig of lavender was also worn by ads and lasses on their way to church. It was considered an emblem of affection, for in "Drayton's Eclogues" (No. 9) we find the following quotation: "He from his lass, him lavender hath sent, showing his love, and doth requital crave." As an ornamental plant Walton again mentions it, for he says that he will lead Venator to an "honest alehouse, where we shall find a cleanly room, lavender in the windows, and twenty ballads stuck about the wall." The singular beauty of the plant that appeals so much to English hearts is the demure gray Quaker-like tint of the whole plant. This is caused by the presence on stem, leaves, and flowers of a dense tomentum or covering of blue stellate hairs and minute glands. Gerarde thus describes the plant, calling it Lavender spike, and figures it as "Lavendula flore coeruleo." "It," he says hath many stiffe branches of a wooddie sub- stance growing up in the manner of a shrubbe, set with many long hoarie leaves, by couples for the most part ; of a strong smell and yet pleasant enough to such as doe love strong savours. The flowers grow at the top of the branches spike fashion of a blue colour." He also speaks of finding in our English gardens a small kinde of lavender lesser than the other the flowers of a more purple colour which did, and I think," he adds, "yet doth row in great plentie in his Majestie's private warden at Whitehall. And this is called spike without addition." In the modern garden we find the lavender plant a frequent feature, and compact bush of the cool looking hairy foliage with the long spikes stretching out with their azure two lipped blossoms, offers a good contrast to other plants. A warm breeze will bring out the perfume of the plant, and as we pass an English garden "opening upon level plots of crowned lilies standing near purple spiked lavender," we can enjoy one of the peculiar delights of a warm July day.

div.head: KIRIN AND THE SUNGARI.
div.p: Two stupendous armies, the largest ever gathered for battle since the days of Tamer- lane, are encamped in one of the loveliest lands on earth. For the Province of Kirin is incomparably beautiful, especially along the Sungari Valley, and its Long White Mountain and its Dragon King's Pool are amongst the wonders of the Far East. In summer the province is one grand garden. In winter over the hard roads and frozen rivers the traffic is immense, for this section of Manchuria con- tains the highways between the northern province of Hei-lung-chiang and Feng-tien in the south. Should peace not be speedily ar- ranged, in a few weeks Kirin will be a terrible Aceldama.

This area of conflict defies description so far as superlative scenic beauty is concerned. In the valleys the lilies of many species grow in riotous profusion, the iris blooms in every creek, and countless autumn crocuses spangle every stretch of sward. The woods are car- peted with the convolvulus and the bluebell. Poppies blaze amongst the dark green millet. Where the forests are thick on the lower slopes of the hills orchids light up the gloom. Azaleas bearing masses of small yellow flowers, colum- bines of every shade of mauve or buff, and great clumps of deep blue gentian variegate the mossy grass of the meadows of this veritable Paradise of Eastern Asia. All travellers agree that Kirin is the garden of Manchuria. Its area of over 90,000 square miles is everywhere attractive with unique features of loveliness.

The pride and the glory of Kirin is the great river which is the noblest tributary of the mighty Amur. The Sungari is Manchu- ria's grandest stream. It rises in a romantic spot, in the bosom of the Ever-White Mountain (Chang-pai-shan), that sacred range which enshrines the Dragon King's Pool in a mar- vellous crater. In that strange lake high up in the mountain is the source of the Erh-tao- chang, the eastern branch of the Sungari. The stream issues from the north end of the great deep pool sacred to the Dragon, who is the God of Rain. Ten miles away, in another nook of the range, is the birth-place of the famous Yalu River, and only thirty miles off is the source of the Tumen. The main stream of the Sungari is born in a wondrous spot, a place of enchantment, in the midst of the musical thunder of grand waterfalls. At the foot of a slope under the ragged needle-like peaks of the Old White Mountain, part of the Long-White Mountain range, burst forth two splendid cascades, each leaping down a precipice 150 feet high. One of these sister falls is the source of the real Sungari. Through the forest below the Dragon King's Pool the stream rushes on, beginning its course of many turns through Kirin amongst mountains, forests, parks, and prairies, till after a track of 850 miles the noble affluent pours its flood into the magnificent Amur at a point 150 miles above Kharbarovsk.

Hundreds of pretty villages and some con- siderable cities stand on the banks of the Sungari. The river is known to the Manchu- rians by the name of Sung-huachiang, or Pine Flower River. The most important cities built on its banks are Kirin, the metropolis of the province, Petuna, Sansing, and Tsicheng. The city of Kirin is an altogether unique place. Its population is not very large for the capital of a province containing eight millions, for there are not more than 100,000 people within its walls. But Kirin is a con- glomeration of singular characteristics. It is a great coffin depot, and a famous inland port.

From the mountain forests immense quanti- ties of timber, chiefly red and yellow pine, are floated down the Sungari to Kirin, which has long been famous as the head centre of the great lumber commerce of the Far East. The Chinese style Kirin "the city of the happy forest" and the native Manchurians call it Chuan Chang, or "The Dockyard, for here large numbers of river junks are skillfully manufactured. It is the most important boat- building emporium in all Manchuria, and as the surrounding districts are rich in minerals and metals, iron and copper abounding, and even gold and silver existing, the city should long since have been a place of immense wealth.

Kirin ought to be an easy city to defend. It is magnificently situated for military pur- poses. Behind it is a semi-circle of low hills, towards which the land at the back of the city gently rises. In front of Kirin sweeps the majestic Sungari, here 1,200 feet broad. The Russians have brought steamers from Khar- barovk as far as Kirin, though higher up than this point the river is only navigable for junks. Kirin should be far more difficult to capture than was Mukden, and the Japanese have a hard nut indeed to crack if the vast Russian forces possess real martial calibre. Both Lienevitch and Rennenkampf are per- fectly familiar with the whole district, as they were actively engaged here in 1900, during the Boxer campaign, after the massacre at Blagovestchenk.

It is in winter that the city of Kirin is at its best. The river is deeply frozen, and makes magnificent high-road for travel and traffic. Along its icy surface, as well as on the roads in every direction from the city, stream great caravans of carts laden with wine, oil, dried mushrooms, deer horns, tea, piece-goods, pick- les, furniture, and coffins. Winter is a busy time. The great, rambling, shabby old inns round the courtyards are crowded. Rows of mules and bullocks are packed in all the available space, eating millet-stalks. Carters coming and going throng the inside of the kang, devouring rice soup, boiled millet, and stewed pork or mutton, and, of course, drink- ing hot wine.
In summer, especially in the rainy season, which is at its height all through August Kirin is an unsavoury place. Sanitation absolutely unknown. The broad Sungari is

apt, at this time of the year, when, flooded by swollen rivulets from the mountains, to overflow its banks, and the western portion of the city is then often swamped for days. All the streets within the old walls (built in the Middle Ages round the city, partly of mud, partly of the roughest masonry) are then intolerably filthy. The pathway of the street along the riverside is on old planks built out on piles. But this only reminds the visitor of the famous Board Walk at Atlantic City, by way of deplorable contrast. Along a great section of this river front are piles of coffins, in which an enormous business is done.

div.head: RUSSIAN JEWS AND REVOLUTION.
div.p: It might be supposed that the Russian Jews, who have been so terribly oppressed by the bureaucracy, would have entered heart and soul into the revolutionary movement in Russia. But this is not the case. The Jewish working classes have joined with their fellows in the resistance to authority, but they have been checked by the Jews of the bourgeoisie, who are influenced more by a dread of a class rising than by affection for Tsarism. The Jews in Russia are as a whole by no means devoted to the bureaucratic regime. Of the thirty-nine nationalities in Russia they come fifth in nu- merical order, and they have suffered worse oppression than any of them. They have always considered themselves as foreigners in the country, and as foreigners who are looked upon with suspicion. They have, therefore, always been anxious not to do anything which could irritate the authorities, and have paid more heed to Jewish interests than to the general good of the Empire. Nationalism on the part of the Jews has never considered the anti- Semitic feeling as a part of the oppression from which Russia as a whole suffers, and the leaders of the race have always preferred to get the best terms possible from the Tsar's Govern- ment rather than to enter on the dangerous path of revolution. The batter class Jews only ask for toleration ; and on that account they are opposed to the revolutionary movement, though the proletariat class, have been inclined to throw in their lot with the Russian workmen.

div.head: THE INCONSIDERATE HAIR.
div.p: Sir Oliver Lodge told us the other day that the man of the future will have no teeth and no toes. But apparently he will still have a beard, in spite of generations of tonsorial discouragement; and the medical journals of 2905 will cry, as the "British Medical Journal'' now does, for "some method of removal at once swifter and easier than the razor." The behaviour of the human hair is, indeed, characterised by a singular perversity. It begins to disappear from the crown or the temples at a period ridiculously in advance of old age ;but who ever heard of baldness of the chin ? A man may shave daily for fifty years, and at three score and tea the stubble will reappear with the exasperating persistency of the thing that is not wanted. It is not merely that the beard is out of fashion. The tendency of progress, the dictates of hygiene, the sordid necessity of cheating the calendar, are all against it—so much against it that it is better worth a man's while to spend ten minutes every morning, razor in hand, rather than go bearded like the pard, or even like the less truculent goat. We believe the Statistical Society has stacked somewhere alarming figures as to the number of years of his life which the average man spends in shaving, and the aggre- gate number of millenniums thus lost to the human race. But how is nature to be made to understand that the age of patriarchs is gone ?

A traveller in a remote part of India—so Mr. Haldane has told us—found the natives offering up a sacrifice to an all-powerful god who had just restored to the tribe the land which the Indian Government had taken from it. "What is the name of the god to whom the sacrifice is offered up," inquired the traveller. "We know nothing of him, but that he is a good god, and that his name is the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council," replied the natives.

div.head: BATHING AT RAMLEH.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Dear Sir,—I have read in the "Egyptian Gazette" of Friday last a letter by a "Mer- maid" which astonishes me. Does the "Mer- maid" believe that all can afford to have bathing-boxes ? and does she think that poor people have no right to bathe in the sea ? which I think does not belong to the mermaids but to all the fishes. If poor Arab families have no money to buy soap with and wash themselves, is it their fault ? I think the Egyptians are decent enough and I believe few, very few indeed, dare insult a respect- able European lady. In European bathing resorts all classes of people bathe together, rich and poor, clean and filthy, and I don't see why there the sights are decent and here they are indecent "A. Hanem "
Cairo, 29th July, 1905.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT
New Issue of Shares for Increase of Capital
div.p: IN PURSUANCE of an Extraordinary Ge- neral Meeting held on the 18th May 1905, the Board of Directors of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt offer 248,000 new shares of the said Bank of Five punds sterling each. These shares will constitute an increase of Capital of the Bank, and are issued in conformity with the Statutes per share, payable on application.

Application should be made :-- in Egyot to the Head Office of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo and to the Branch at Alexandria. in London to the London Agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 &5, King William Street, E.C.
The new shares will rank for dividende from the 1st January 1906, that is to say from the beginning of next year.
Every shareholder has the right on applica- tion to an allotment of one new share in respect of every old share held.

All shareholders who wish to excercise their rights must, under pain of forfeiture of those rights, lodge their applications at one of the places named above on or before the 2nd October 1905 depositing their Share Warrants together with the total amount payable, viz : £ 5 per share.
The President of the Board of Directors, (signed) ELWIN PALMER
Cairo, the 8th July 1905.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
